questions.text: A 60-year-old man who has worked in the zinc mines presents to his urologist with urinary symptoms, including increased frequency, hesitancy, and nocturia. During a digital rectal examination, he is found to have an enlarged prostate with a palpable nodule. Which environmental exposure is most likely associated with his prostate cancer risk?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cadmium

 

Explanation:

Occupational exposure to cadmium, commonly found in industries such as zinc mining, smelting of zinc ores, and battery manufacturing, has been associated with an increased risk of prostate cancer.

Zinc (Option A): Excessive zinc exposure does not have a direct association with prostate cancer.

Benzopyrene (Option B): It is associated with increased risks of lung cancer, bladder cancer, skin cancer, and other malignancies.

Arsenic (Option C): It is associated with an increased risk of angiosarcoma of the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with vinyl chloride exposure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hepatic angiosarcoma

 

Explanation:

Vinyl chloride exposure is associated with hepatic angiosarcoma (cancer that arises from the blood vessels).

3 chemicals cause hepatic angiosarcoma: 

  • Vinyl chloride
  • Arsenic
  • Thorotrast

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A): Typically associated with cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B or C infections due to HBV or HCV, alcohol abuse, or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option C): Cholangiocarcinoma (carcinoma of the biliary duct in the liver) includes Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), liver fluke infections such as Clonorchis and Opisthorchis, or certain biliary tract disorders.

Focal nodular hyperplasia (Option D): FNH is more prevalent in women and is associated with hormonal imbalances.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with a clear-cell vaginal tumour. Upon further inquiry, it was revealed that her mother has a history of taking medication during pregnancy to prevent premature labour. Which medication is most likely associated with the development of this tumour in the daughter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DES (Diethylstilbestrol)

 

Explanation: 

DES (Diethylstilbestrol), a synthetic estrogen previously administered to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and pregnancy complications, has been associated with a significantly increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the cervix or vagina in daughters exposed to it in utero. 

Thalidomide (Option B): Causes severe birth defects like limb deformities (phocomelia), blindness, deafness, heart issues, and brain damage in babies. It is a teratogen, not a carcinogen.

Tamoxifen (Option C): Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the treatment of ER-positive breast cancer.

Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Option D): Long-term use or high doses of MPA, particularly in combination with estrogen, may increase the risk of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indirect-acting carcinogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nitrosoureas

 

Explanation:

Nitrosoureas are a direct-acting carcinogenic agent.

 

Characteristic

Direct-Acting Carcinogens

Indirect-Acting Carcinogens

Mode of action

Directly damage DNA, leading to mutations

Require metabolic conversion to become active (ultimate carcinogens)

Carcinogenic potency

Typically weak

More potent

Endogenous enzymes involved

None

Cytochrome P-450

Examples
  • Alkylating agents (Anti-cancer drugs) like nitrosoureas, cyclophosphamide
  • Acylating agents
  • Aromatic hydrocarbons like benzo[a]pyrene
  • Aromatic Amines, Amides, Azo Dyes (Option B ruled out)
  • Natural Plant and Microbial Products like Aflatoxin B1, Griseofulvin, and Betel nuts (Options A, D ruled out)
  • Insecticides, fungicides

questions.text: Which of the following radiations is the most common cause of skin cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) UV-B radiation

 

Explanation:

UV-B radiation is the major cause of sunburn and skin cancer.

  • Wavelengths: 280-320 nm
  • It is responsible for inducing the formation of pyrimidine dimers within DNA, leading to mutations that can result in various types of skin cancer:
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Basal cell carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma.


 

UV-A radiation (Option A): Wavelengths: 320-400 nm. They primarily cause skin ageing. UV-A radiation, particularly in combination with UV-B, can increase the risk of skin cancer.

UV-C radiation (Option C): These shorter wavelengths (200-280 nm) are extremely potent in terms of DNA damage, but they are largely filtered out by the Earth's ozone layer and do not reach the surface in significant amounts.

UV-D radiation (Option D): The UV spectrum typically consists of UV-A, UV-B, and UV-C and no UV-D radiation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female radiology technician with 25 years of occupational exposure to diagnostic X-rays and fluoroscopy presents with a three-month history of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and frequent infections. Which cancer type is most likely associated with her occupational history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation:

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a type of blood cancer commonly associated with prolonged exposure to ionizing radiation, such as X-rays and γ-rays, placing affected individuals at increased risk of developing the disease

  • The most common thyroid cancer associated with ionising radiations: Papillary carcinoma thyroid
  • Cancer which is never associated with ionising radiations: CLL

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for a routine gynaecological examination. Her Pap smear and biopsy reveals abnormal cells suggestive of cervical dysplasia. Further, HPV testing indicates the presence of specific HPV types associated with cervical cancer. Which HPV types are most commonly linked to an increased risk of cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) High-risk 16, 18

 

Explanation:

The abnormal cells in the pap smear and biopsy are known as Koilocytes, characterised by a raisinoid nucleus and a perinuclear halo, which indicates HPV infection.

  • High-risk HPV types like HPV 16 and HPV 18 are strongly linked to a higher risk of cervical cancer, including high-grade cervical dysplasia and invasive cancer.
  • Low-risk HPV types such as HPV 6 and HPV 11 are often associated with genital warts such as condyloma acuminatum and low-grade changes in cervical cells (Option A ruled out).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles undergoes routine Pap smear screening, which reveals a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix. Further testing confirms infection with high-risk HPV type 16. Which of the following mechanisms regarding the oncogenic activity of E6 and E7 of HPV is correct?

choices.text: E6 protein inhibits the degradation of p53.
E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.
E7 can inactivate cyclins A and E

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.

 

Explanation:

E6 and E7 proteins from high-risk HPV types exhibit increased affinity for key cellular regulatory proteins (e.g., p53, RB) compared to low-risk HPV types.
 

Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein

Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein
  • Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 (policeman of the cell) → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation (Option A ruled out).
  • Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.
  • Disrupts interaction between RB gene (governor of genome) and E2F transcription factors
  • Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27) (Option C ruled out).
  • Activates cyclins A and E (Option D ruled out)
 

All these mechanisms enhance cell cycle progression and cellular proliferation in HPV infections.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with rapidly growing jaw swelling and pain. Further examination reveals bilateral enlargement of the mandible and maxilla. Biopsy suggests the presence of a starry-sky appearance as shown in the image. Which of the following infectious agents is most commonly associated with the pathogenesis of this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) EBV

 

Explanation:

The image displays a characteristic "starry sky" appearance, which is typically seen in Burkitt's lymphoma, a type of aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.

  • The ‘starry sky pattern’ of histopathology represents scattered macrophages with phagocytosed cell debris among proliferating lymphoma cells is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.
    • Stars (Lighter cells): Macrophages
    • Sky (dark blue cells in background): Tumorous cells of Burkitt lymphoma
  • Burkitt Lymphoma: Most commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which is endemic in central Africa and New Guinea, where it is the most common childhood tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding H. pylori infection and its association with malignancies is correct?

choices.text: Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.
H. pylori strains associated with gastric adenocarcinomas contain the cytotoxin-associated B gene.
VacA, a toxin from H. pylori, causes gastric cell apoptosis, reducing cancer risk.
MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) translocation respond to anti-H.Pylori therapy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.

 

Explanation:

Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.

  • Lymphoma caused by H. pylori is known as Maltoma, which is a marginal zone lymphoma belonging to B-cell origin.
  • Maltomas of the stomach have 2 ways of having pathogenesis:
    1. Occurring because of H. pylori infection, which can be treated with anti-H. pylori or antibiotic therapy.
    2. Due to t(11,18) translocation: Because of the presence of chromosomal disorders,  anti-H. pylori or antibiotic therapy would not work. (Option D ruled out)
  • Other cancer of the stomach, which is caused by H. pylori: Gastric adenocarcinoma
    • ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​2 genes responsible for causing gastric adenocarcinoma are CagA and VacA proteins (Options B and C ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the following carcinogens with the respective cancer risk

 


	
		
			
			1. Azodyes
			
			
			a) Urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
			
		
		
			
			2. Schistosoma haematobium
			
			
			b) AML & ALL
			
		
		
			
			3. Radon
			
			
			c) Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder
			
		
		
			
			4. Benzene
			
			
			d) Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-a, 2-c, 3- d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

Risk factor

Cancer risk

Azodyes/ Beta naphthyl amine/Benzidine

Urothelial carcinoma/ Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder

Schistosoma haematobium

Squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder

Radon

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

Benzene

AML & ALL (Blood cancers)
